ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was the best course I've taken at F&ES - rigorous, engaging, well-organized, complex. Prof.Seto is a phenomenal professor and it is clear she put a lot of work into this course.
This course was amazing!!!!!!!!!!!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Write synthesis.

I cannot say enough positive things about this course. Karen's dynamic teaching style kept every class interesting and different. Students were constantly engaged and asked to think/learn/communicate in new ways. There should be more classes at FES taught this way!

The best aspects of this course were the assignments, readings, and class discussions, and how they all complemented one another to provide substantive knowledge of the material, but practice in skills such as synthesis writing, public speaking, and policy analysis.
Best-taught course at FES. Instructor shows actual interest in student learning! Subject area is very interesting. Readings on-point.
The layout of class time made offered opportunities to practice a lot of different skills...class neverfelt slow.

Everything we do and the order we do it in really makes the information sink in and turns you in kind of an expert in the subject. Starting with learning to properly read the literature, learning to write synthesis (a skill so essential but apparently few know), reading a commenting on classmates work, and finally having an class filled with great exercise and loads of in-class discussion. All of these things in a week make it a heavy course, but so worth it!

The heavy reading load and weekly synthesis exercise were tremendously valuable in terms of generating accountability among the students and ensuring a high level of discussion during class. The interactive class activities were well-designed and valuable too.
I enjoyed the format of the course

Everything! The readings were great and relevant! Learning to write syntheses is challenging but very necessary and allowed me to thoroughly gain an understanding of the readings.The class discussions could have gone on for hours!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More feedback from the instructor. Hope to see more comments on assignment

I think the S&As (weekly assignments) were graded somewhat arbitrarily. Sometimes I had lots of comments, sometimes I had none. The ones I felt the best about, I usually did the worst on. It felt a bit like the grading was inevitably going to improve over time, and that your grade was more about how to motivate you to keep working than it was a reflection of the quality of your work.Also, a little much to have policy memos and S&As due the same week.
Can't think of anything that should be done differently...
I don't think the policy memos were that useful as I am not interested in policy in general.
Nothing

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No discussion/lab section
Very effective

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Satisfy my interest in urban planning.
Great link between energy and cities - which are my two primary interests. Very necessary class and subject to have at FES!
I'm not necessarily planning on getting into urban studies, but a lot of the skills we practiced would be highly relevant to most areas of study/career paths.

The course made me realize the importance of climate change in places like cities. I love studying cities and how to make them more sustainable and human places, this class made me realize the actual extent to which cities can become global key players in mitigating/innovating on climate change issues.

I'm interested in urban systems, and as one of the only courses offered at F&ES focused on urban issues, it was tremendously valuable for helping me build foundational knowledge around greenhouse gas mitigation in urban areas.
Climate change and urban areas are the way of the future--knowing what drives them and the relationship between policies and change is critical for anyone wanting to work in these fields!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because of the professor and my interest in urban planning
I am interested in urban areas, and I also felt I would be remiss if I didn't take a Climate Change course while at FES.
Because I knew it was taught well, and that the professor actually cared about teaching.
Because every person how took it before me recommended it. They were right.
I was seeking a demanding and intellectually rigorous course. This class has an excellent reputation among the students who have taken it.
I wanted to take a course with Karen Seto before leaving and I plan to work in urban environments the rest of my career so it was a perfect fit!

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I don't think I have gained the skills of writing policy memos.
They exceeded my expectations. This course has made me a better writer and speaker, and has increased my confidence in terms of communicating about science.
This course both met and exceeded my expectations.
Yes and far exceeded!
Yes, definitely felt like my most "productive" course this semester.
Yes, more than expected.
Absolutely. I would take the course again to dive more deeply into some of the issues.
YES and then some!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The time for group work is very short. It is hard for me to keep up with the fast pace.
The difficulty but advantage of the partner writing assignment was having to conduct research, writing, and editing with someone with a different writing style and narrative "voice."
It was interesting tothink through the first policy memo with a peer and to find ways of integrating our perspectives and skill sets into a cohesive narrative.
Advantages--idea sharingDisadvantages--having to rely on others. This is just a control issue, not reflective of the course

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it.
TAKE THIS COURSE! Even if Climate Change isn't your main area of interest, the skills you will get from the course will extend to all areas of your life.
Even if climate change mitigation in urban areas is not your particular area of interest or expertise, the knowledge and skills you will gain from this course are widely applicable.
Be ready for the workload, but it's worth it.

Do it, you wont regret it. It is definitely a heavier workload than most FES courses, but a great writing/speaking/learning experience. Karen taught me how to properly write and make a case for fighting climate change in urban areas.Even if your thing is not urban, the skills you gain from the course are useful in any subject. Synthesizing, persuasive writing, speaking and discussing, and working in groups.
This is a demanding course requiring critical engagement with the materials. It is well worth the effort, and may be the best course offered at F&ES.

Tailor your other courses so that you can prioritize this one! It has a huge and heavy work load, so make sure you are able to give it the time and dedication Seto expects! She puts even more time in to this course than you will which is reflective of how amazing she is as a professor! If you don't put in the required effort you will get nothing out of this class, so bother even taking it.This is probably the only class at FES (or any course ever) where the heavy workload is a benefit and actually worth the students' time!
